ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Omg so many. I essentially learned how to write fiction, which I had barely done before. It really is one of those things you can only learn by jumping into the deep end and just TRYING it.

This course taught me how to approach a big writing project, break it up into manageable parts, report it, write it, and edit it. This class was transformative for my writing and has given me the confidence to attempt large writing projects in the future.
I learned how to develop a longer creative project from scratch within a short amount of time.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I mean...it's not really a "course" per se. It was just me and my word doc, mostly. I think it was a good balance of freedom and advisor interaction, if that helps.

The course was incredible; the frequent meetings with my cohort and advisor were incredibly useful in keeping me on track and enabling me to share difficulties and insight throughout the process, and the general meetings with the writing concentrators provided inspiration to keep writing despite the challenges. Overall a wonderful experience.

The way that the concentration project is largely self-directed could be a strength or a weakness, just because there are not many other Yale assignments like it, so it can involve a pretty big adjustment to the way that you work. Every advisor approaches the concentration in a slightly different way, and my advisor was perfect for me, so it worked out very well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you want to write fiction, do it.

YES!! Be a writing concentrator!!! You will never have a chance like this to commit to a long writing project on any topic you want with incredible support from peers and advisors. There is so much room to grow as a writer and collaborator, and presenting the finished piece at the concentrator's ball was one of the best experiences of my senior year.
It's the thesis/ senior project for the writing concentration, so you know if you need to take this.
